Award.AbstractNarration:
This project supports three years of MIT Talbot workshops. This is an annual event organized by graduate students. The 2014 MIT Talbot Workshop took place March 16-22 in Pigeon Forge, Tennessee. Professor Marc Levine of the Universitaet Duisburg-Essen led the workshop, which was entitled Motivic Homotopy Theory. Since their initiation in 2004, the MIT Talbot Workshops have provided a unique opportunity for some thirty young researchers - graduate students and postdocs - to spend a week with an expert in their field in an intimate and informal setting. Each workshop is on a different topic, chosen for its broad interest and currency. Qualities of clarity, leadership, and generosity are important in the selection of mentor. Numerous strong research relationships have had their origin in these workshops over the years.

Motivic homotopy theory, the subject of the 2014 workshop, is a vibrant and rapidly expanding research area with origins in the solution of the Milnor conjecture about algebraic K-theory by Vladimir Voevodsky (who won the Fields Medal for this work). It has attracted an increasing number of participants from both algebraic geometry and algebraic topology, because of its intrinsic beauty and its proven power as a tool for attacking problems in algebraic K-theory and, more recently, in homotopy theory. It provided an ideal subject for the Talbot Workshop, bringing together very bright and motivated young researchers from distinct fields in a context which encouraged deep learning and collaboration, under the inspired leadership of Marc Levine, one who has made profound contributions to the subject.

The website http://math.mit.edu/conferences/talbot/ contains descriptions of and reports resulting from all eleven MIT Talbot Workshops.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Talbot Workshop is an annual retreat at which young mathematicians, chiefly graduate students, gather to learn about a topic of current research in algebraic topology. The graduate student leadership selects a faculty mentor, or, in recent years, two. The precise topic is then chosen by the mentors. Over the course of a week, participants deliver a series of lectures based on a syllabus devised by the faculty mentors. These lectures are typically framed by orienting lectures by the mentors. Much of the mathematical activity of the workshop actually occurs outside of the lectures, either in organized question sessions or spontaneous conversations among the participants and the mentors. NSF funding was used to support travel and local expenses for 30-40 participants at each workshop. 

This grant supported three workshops. The 2014 Talbot Workshop on Motivic Homotopy Theory was mentored by Marc Levine (Professor, Universität Duisburg-Essen) and Bradley Drew (Postdoctoral Researcher, Universit\"at Duisburg-Essen). The 2015 Talbot Workshop on Little Disks Operads was mentored by Kathryn Hess (Professor, École Polytechnique Fédérale de Lausanne) and Dev Sinha (Professor, University of Oregon). The 2016 Talbot Workshop on Equivariant Stable Homotopy Theory and the Kervaire Invariant was mentored by Michael Hill (Professor, University of California, Los Angeles) and Douglas Ravenel (Professor, University of Rochester). 

The Talbot Workshops provide an exceptional opportunity for the professional development of young mathematicians. Unlike most other academic conferences, the Talbot Workshop immerses participants in a communal environment. Aside from the many hours to discuss mathematics, participants get to know each other while collaborating on more routine projects such as preparing dinners and going on hikes. This setting encourages participants to build academic relationships and strengths the community of young researchers.

The Workshops also stimulate creation of weekly seminars at several institutions across the country in advance, to prepare participants. And it has spawned at least three other workshops: the “European Talbot Workshop” in algebraic topology that has run since 2015 along very similar lines, and two workshops on symplectic topology.

The Talbot Workshop leadership maintains a website presenting a detailed account of the activities, along with lecture notes by participants and occasionally by a mentor as well. This record of a systematic presentation of an important current research topic has proven to be a valuable world-readable resource.

Talbot is also committed to promoting diversity in the mathematical community. In particular, under this grant, the workshop has made a special effort to promote gender diversity. In 2015, 14 of 34 participants were women, and in 2016, 13 of 36 participants were women. Many of these participants remarked that the large number of female participants helped them learn and network.
